question_text: How does the oxidant composition (air vs. oxygen/steam) affect the syngas heating value and oxygen utilization in underground coal gasification, and what are the underlying chemical mechanisms?
standard_answer: The oxidant composition significantly impacts syngas heating value and oxygen utilization through stoichiometric and thermodynamic principles. Air-blown gasification introduces nitrogen, which dilutes the syngas, reducing its heating value to 4–5 MJ/Nm³. In contrast, oxygen/steam gasification eliminates nitrogen dilution, allowing higher concentrations of combustible gases like H₂ and CO, increasing heating values to 10–11 MJ/Nm³. Oxygen utilization, defined as energy in syngas per kmol of injected oxygen, improves from ~950 MJ/kmol with air to ~1200 MJ/kmol with oxygen/steam due to enhanced reaction efficiency. The Boudouard reaction (C + CO₂ ⇌ 2CO) and water-gas shift (CO + H₂O ⇌ CO₂ + H₂) are promoted under oxygen/steam conditions, favoring endothermic gasification reactions over exothermic combustion. Higher temperatures from oxygen enrichment accelerate kinetics, while steam injection moderates temperature via endothermic reactions, preventing slagging and optimizing gas composition. This balance maximizes carbon conversion and syngas energy density.
